head.title: How Bias-Victims Law Provides New Redress

hedline.hl1: How Bias-Victims Law Provides New Redress

block.p: A Jan. 7 news article incorrectly characterizes a civil bias law passed by the New York City Council. This legislation grants victims of bias-related violence for the first time the right to seek redress before the city's Human Rights Commission or in the courts and to obtain damages.

A Jan. 7 news article incorrectly characterizes a civil bias law passed by the New York City Council. This legislation grants victims of bias-related violence for the first time the right to seek redress before the city's Human Rights Commission or in the courts and to obtain damages.

Previously, the only power to seek such redress was in the city's corporation counsel. That office could, at the commission's request or on its own, commence a court action for civil penalties to be awarded to the city as a result of such violence. Such an action could not have been commended before the commission.
Moreover, victims had no right to compel the corporation counsel so to act or even to consider a bias-violence complaint.
Speaker Peter F. Vallone and Councilwoman Kathryn Freed, the law's author and key sponsor, are to be commended for their leadership in passing this law. ARTHUR J. LEVY Brooklyn, Jan. 15, 1993
The writer has led the Lesbian and Gay Law Association of Greater New York's legislative committee.
